body.p: DECAY OF SOLUTIONS OF SOME NONLINEAR EQUATIONS

Abstract: For a class of scalar partial differential equations that incorporate convection, diffusion, and possibly dispersion in one space and one time dimension, the stability of solutions is investigated.
The topic of this paper is the class of equations

m:math.alttext: u_{t}-\alpha u_{xx}+\beta u_{xxx}+\gamma u_{xxxxt}+(g(u))_{x}=0,\ x\in\mathbb{% R},\ t>0

m:semantics.m:annotation: u_{t}-\alpha u_{xx}+\beta u_{xxx}+\gamma u_{xxxxt}+(g(u))_{x}=0,\ x\in\mathbb{% R},\ t>0

body.p: where subscripts denote partial derivatives. The case ùëîùë¢superscriptùë¢22g‚Å¢(u)=u22g(u)=\displaystyle\frac{u^{2}}{2} and ùõæ0Œ≥=0\gamma=0 is typical and has received much attention. If formulae-sequenceùõº0ùõΩ0Œ±>0,Œ≤=0\alpha>0,\beta=0, this is known as Burgers equation. If formulae-sequenceùõº0ùõΩ0Œ±=0,Œ≤>0\alpha=0,\beta>0, this is essentially the Korteweg-de-Vries equation. The case formulae-sequenceùõº0ùõΩ0Œ±>0,Œ≤>0\alpha>0,\beta>0 is thus refereed to as KdVKdV\mathrm{K}\mathrm{d}\mathrm{V}-Burgers equation; it also has been studied extensively as has been the case of general ùëîgg. The case ùëîùë¢superscriptùë¢ùëù1ùëù1g‚Å¢(u)=up+1p+1g(u)=\displaystyle\frac{u^{p+1}}{p+1} and formulae-sequenceùõæ1ùõΩ0Œ≥=1,Œ≤=0\gamma=1,\beta=0 where ùëù1p‚â•1p\geq 1 is an integer is refereed to as the Rosenau-Burgers equation. Indeed, if ùõº0Œ±=0\alpha=0 then we have the Rosenau equation proposed by Rosenau 8 for treating the dynamics of dense discrette systems in order to overcome the shortenings by the KdVKdV\mathrm{K}\mathrm{d}\mathrm{V} equation, since the KdVKdV\mathrm{K}\mathrm{d}\mathrm{V} equation describes unidimensional propagation of waves, but wave-wave and wave-wall interactions cannot be treated by it. Such a model were studied by Park 9 and Chung and Ha 3 for the global existence of the solution to the IBVP. Equation (1.1) with formulae-sequenceùõº0formulae-sequenceùõæ1ùõΩ0Œ±>0,Œ≥=1,Œ≤=0\alpha>0,\gamma=1,\beta=0 is called the Rosenau- Burgers equation and somehow corresponds to the KdVKdV\mathrm{K}\mathrm{d}\mathrm{V}-Burgers equation and the BenjaBonaBenja‚Å¢min-Bona\displaystyle\mathrm{B}\mathrm{e}\mathrm{n}\mathrm{j}\mathrm{a}\min-\mathrm{B}% \mathrm{o}\mathrm{n}\mathrm{a}-Mahoney-Burgers equation, but it is given neither by Rosenau nor by Burgers. The Rosenau equation with the dissipative term ùõºsubscriptùë¢ùë•ùë•-Œ±‚Å¢ux‚Å¢x-\alpha u_{xx}, or say, the Rosenau-Burgers equation arises in some natural phenomena as for example, in bore propagation and in water waves.
In section 2 of this paper, we study the problem (1.1) with formulae-sequenceùõΩ1ùõæ0Œ≤=1,Œ≥=0\beta=1,\gamma=0:

where ùõº0Œ±>0\alpha>0 and ùëîgg is a superscriptùê∂2C2C^{2}-class function. We give a general criterion for the existence of traveling wave solutions of the form ùë¢ùë•ùë°italic-œïùë•ùëêùë°u‚Å¢(x,t)=œï‚Å¢(x-c‚Å¢t)u(x,\ t)=\phi(x-ct) .
In section 3, we study the asymptotic behaviour of the solution for the Rosenau- Burgers equation (problem (1.1) with formulae-sequenceùõΩ0ùõæ1Œ≤=0,Œ≥=1\beta=0,\gamma=1):
The problem (E2) was studied by Mei 7. He proved that if subscript‚Ñùsubscriptùë¢0ùë•differential-dùë•0‚à´‚Ñùu0‚Å¢(x)‚Å¢ùëëx‚â†0\int_{\mathbb{R}}u_{0}(x)dx\neq 0 then

Hence, it is proved in 7 that 00 is the asymptotic state of the solution ùë¢ùë•ùë°u‚Å¢(x,t)u(x,\ t) for the Rosenau-Burgers equation. In this paper, we prove that the solution of the nonlinear parabolic equation subscriptùë¢ùë°ùõºsubscriptùë¢ùë•ùë•subscriptsuperscriptùë¢ùëù1ùëù1ùë•0ut-Œ±‚Å¢ux‚Å¢x+(up+1p+1)x=0u_{t}-\displaystyle\alpha u_{xx}+(\frac{u^{p+1}}{p+1})_{x}=0 is a better asymptotic proflle for the Rosenau-Burgers equation. Furthermore, we prove that the convergence to this asymptotic proflle is faster than the convergence to 00 proved in 7.
Before ending this section, we state and prove a general technical lemma which will be needed later.

Under certain conditions, the equation admits monotone traveling wave solu- tions ùë¢ùë•ùë°italic-œïùë•ùëêùë°u‚Å¢(x,t)=œï‚Å¢(x-c‚Å¢t)u(x,\ t)=\phi(x-ct) with speed ùëêcc that connect the end states subscriptitalic-œïplus-or-minussubscript‚Üíùëüplus-or-minusitalic-œïùëüœï¬±=limr‚Üí¬±‚àû‚Å°œï‚Å¢(r)\displaystyle\phi_{\pm}=\lim_{r\rightarrow\pm\infty}\phi(r) . Such a wave proflle must satisfy the third order ordinary difierential equation

An example is ùëîùë•2ùë•ùë•1ùëèùë•g‚Å¢(x)=2‚Å¢x‚Å¢(x-1)‚Å¢(b-x)g(x)=2x(x-1)(b-x) with ùëè2b‚â•2b\geq 2, which has the wave profile italic-œïùë•11superscriptùëíùë•œï‚Å¢(x)=11+ex\displaystyle\phi(x)=\frac{1}{1+e^{x}} for the parameter ùõº2ùëè1Œ±=2‚Å¢b-1\alpha=2b-1 and the speed ùëê0c=0c=0. General profiles (non necessarily monotone) have been constructed in 15. It is known that monotone proflles exist for ùëîùë¢superscriptùë¢ùëù1ùëù1g‚Å¢(u)=up+1p+1g(u)=\displaystyle\frac{u^{p+1}}{p+1} and ùõº2ùëùùëêŒ±‚â•2‚Å¢p‚Å¢c\alpha\geq 2\sqrt{pc}. More generally, we have the following criterion:
Theorem 2.1. Letùëîsuperscriptùê∂2g‚ààC2g\in C^{2}be a strictly convex function. A monotone wave profileitalic-œïœï\phiforùê∏ùëô(E‚Å¢l)(El)exists if only if:
The proflle must therefore be monotonically decreasingProof:

Then, ùëìff is concave, and ùõºsuperscriptùúì‚Ä≤superscriptùúì‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ùëìùúì-Œ±‚Å¢œà‚Ä≤-œà‚Ä≤‚Ä≤=f‚Å¢(œà)-\alpha\psi^{{}^{\prime}}-\psi^{{}^{\prime\prime}}=f(\psi) which is the equation for a wave profile ùúìœà\psi of the Fisher-Kolmogorov-Petrovskii-Piskunov (F-KPP) equation subscriptùë£ùë°subscriptùë£ùë•ùë•ùëìùë£vt-vx‚Å¢x=f‚Å¢(v)v_{t}-v_{xx}=f(v) that travels to the right with speed ùõºŒ±\alpha and has limits formulae-sequencesubscriptùúìsubscriptitalic-œïsubscriptitalic-œïsubscriptùúì0œà-=œï--œï+,œà+=0\psi_{-}=\phi_{-}-\phi_{+},\psi_{+}=0.

Thanks to 4, we know that such a monotone wave profile for concave ùëìff exists if and only if ùõº2superscriptùëì‚Ä≤02superscriptùëî‚Ä≤subscriptitalic-œïùëêŒ±‚â•2‚Å¢f‚Ä≤‚Å¢(0)=2‚Å¢g‚Ä≤‚Å¢(œï-)-c\alpha\geq 2\sqrt{f^{{}^{\prime}}(0)}=2\sqrt{g^{{}^{\prime}}(\phi_{-})-c}. In this case, subscriptùúìsubscriptùúìœà->œà+\psi_{-}>\psi_{+} and therefore subscriptitalic-œïsubscriptitalic-œïœï->œï+\phi_{-}>\phi_{+}, since ùëìff is positive between subscriptùúìœà-\psi_{-} and subscriptùúìœà+\psi_{+}. Thus (2.2)-(2.3) are true.

Define ùëìff as in (2.4), then by known results about the F-KPP equation, there exists a unique decreasing wave profile ùúìœà\psi with ùúì0subscriptitalic-œïsubscriptitalic-œï2œà‚Å¢(0)=œï--œï+2\psi(0)=\frac{\phi_{-}-\phi_{+}}{2} that moves to the right with speed ùõºŒ±\alpha. Then, italic-œïùëßsubscriptitalic-œïùúìùëßœï‚Å¢(z)=œï--œà‚Å¢(-z)\phi(z)=\phi_{-}-\psi(-z) is a monotone wave profile for (E1) with italic-œïplus-or-minussubscriptitalic-œïplus-or-minusœï‚Å¢(¬±‚àû)=œï¬±\phi(\pm\infty)=\phi_{\pm}

Consider the Rosenau-Burgers equation in the form casessubscriptùë¢ùë°ùõºsubscriptùë¢ùë•ùë•subscriptùë¢ùë•ùë•ùë•ùë•ùë°subscriptsuperscriptùë¢ùëù1ùëù1ùë•0formulae-sequenceùë•‚Ñùùë°0ùë¢ùë•Osubscriptùë¢0ùë•‚Üí0asùë•‚Üíplus-or-minusmissing-subexpression{ut-Œ±‚Å¢ux‚Å¢x+ux‚Å¢x‚Å¢x‚Å¢x‚Å¢t+(up+1p+1)x=0,x‚àà‚Ñù,t>0,u‚Å¢(x,O)=u0‚Å¢(x)‚Üí0‚Å¢as‚Å¢x‚Üí¬±‚àû,\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}u_{t}-\alpha u_{xx}+u_{xxxxt}+(\frac{u^{p+1}}{p+1})_% {x}=0,&x\in\mathbb{R},\ t>0,\\ u(x,\ \mathrm{O})=u_{0}(x)\rightarrow 0\ \mathrm{a}\mathrm{s}\ x\rightarrow\pm% \infty,&\end{array}\right.
where ùõºŒ±\alpha is any given constant, ùëù1p‚â•1p\geq 1 is integer.

The solution of this parabolic equation should be a better asymptotic profile of equation (E2).

Theorem 3.1 (1011) Suppose that subscriptùë£0ùë•superscriptùêª2‚Ñùsuperscriptùêø1‚Ñùv0‚Å¢(x)‚ààH2‚Å¢(‚Ñù)‚à©L1‚Å¢(‚Ñù)v_{0}(x)\in H^{2}(\mathbb{R})\cap L^{1}(\mathbb{R}) . body.p: The main result in this section is the following:

Let assignùõºsubscriptnormsubscriptùë£0superscriptùêø1subscriptnormsubscriptùë£0superscriptùêª6Œ±:=‚à•v0‚à•L1+‚à•v0‚à•H6\alpha:=\|v_{0}\|_{L^{1}}+\|v_{0}\|_{H^{6}}, it then there exists a positive constant subscriptùõø0Œ¥0\delta_{0} it such that if

then the Cauchy problem (E2) has a unique global solution ùë¢ùë•ùë°u‚Å¢(x,t)u(x,\ t) with ùë¢ùë•ùë°ùë£ùë•ùë°ùê∂subscript‚Ñùsuperscriptùêª1Ru‚Å¢(x,t)-v‚Å¢(x,t)‚ààC‚Å¢(‚Ñù+,H1‚Å¢(R))u(x,\ t)-v(x,\ t)\in C(\mathbb{R}_{+},\ H^{1}(\mathrm{R})) and satisfies
Corollary 3.3. Under the hypotheses of theorem 3.2, we have for 2ùëû12‚â§q‚â§12\leq q\leq 1 the decay rates
The result in the corollary follows from the interpolation inequality
The rest of the paper is devoted to the proof of theorem 3.2.

Since ùë£plus-or-minusùë°0v‚Å¢(¬±‚àû,t)=0v(\pm\infty,\ t)=0, and we expect formulae-sequenceùë¢plus-or-minusùë°0subscriptùë¢ùë•plus-or-minusùë°0u‚Å¢(¬±‚àû,t)=0,ux‚Å¢(¬±‚àû,t)=0u(\pm\infty,\ t)=0,u_{x}(\pm\infty,\ t)=0, then after integrating (3.12) over ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R}, we get

The inverse Fourier transform of the above resultant equation yields
The difierentiation with respect to ùë•xx of (3.18) gives
Now, we deflne the solution spaces as follows, for any positive integer ùëù1p‚â•1p\geq 1 and given ùõø0Œ¥>0\delta>0:

Rewriting (3.18) as the operational form ùë§ùëÜùë§w=S‚Å¢ww=Sw, we need to prove that ùëÜSS is a contraction mapping from superscriptsubscriptùëÜùëùùõøSpŒ¥S_{p}^{\delta} into superscriptsubscriptùëÜùëùùõøSpŒ¥S_{p}^{\delta} where ùõø0Œ¥>0\delta>0 is a positive constant.
Theorem 3.4. Under the hypotheses of theorem 3.2, there exists a positive constant subscriptùõø1Œ¥1\delta_{1} such that if
then Cauchy problem ( 3.16) has a unique global solution ùë§ùë•ùë°ùê∂subscript‚Ñùsuperscriptùêª2‚Ñùw‚Å¢(x,t)‚ààC‚Å¢(‚Ñù+,H2‚Å¢(‚Ñù))w(x,\ t)\in C(\mathbb{R}_{+},\ H^{2}(\mathbb{R})) .
Furthermore, we have the following estimates:
(i) If ùëù1p=1p=1, then for any ùúÇ0Œ∑>0\eta>0 we have

Since ùë¢ùë•ùë°ùë£ùë•ùë°subscriptùë§ùë•ùë•ùë°u‚Å¢(x,t)-v‚Å¢(x,t)=wx‚Å¢(x,t)u(x,\ t)-v(x,\ t)=w_{x}(x,\ t) , once we prove theorem 3.1, then theorem 3.2 can be easily proved. Hence, we prove theorem 3.1 in the rest of the paper. We need to this end two lemmas and two well-known estimates quoted from 7:
Lemma 3.5. Let subscriptùë§1ùë•ùë°w1‚Å¢(x,t)w_{1}(x,\ t) , subscriptùë§2ùë•ùë°superscriptsubscriptùëÜùëùùõøw2‚Å¢(x,t)‚ààSpŒ¥w_{2}(x,\ t)\in S_{p}^{\delta}, then we have

Proof of Theorem 3.1: Rewriting (3.18) in the form ùë§ùëÜùë§w=S‚Å¢ww=Sw, we need to prove that there exists a positive constant subscriptùõø1Œ¥1\delta_{1} such that the operator ùëÜSS is a contraction mapping from superscriptsubscriptùëÜsuperscriptùëù1ùõøSp1Œ¥S_{p^{1}}^{\delta} into superscriptsubscriptùëÜsuperscriptùëù1ùõøSp1Œ¥.S_{p^{1}}^{\delta}.

We claim that ùëÜSS maps superscriptsubscriptùëÜùëùùõøSpŒ¥S_{p}^{\delta} into itself. Indeed, for any subscriptùë§1ùë•ùë°superscriptsubscriptùëÜùëùùõøw1‚Å¢(x,t)‚ààSpŒ¥w_{1}(x,\ t)\in S_{p}^{\delta} and denoting ùë§ùëÜsubscriptùë§1w=S‚Å¢w1w=Sw_{1} we will prove that ùë§superscriptsubscriptùëÜùëùùõøw‚ààSpŒ¥w\in S_{p}^{\delta} for some small ùõø0Œ¥>0\delta>0. Thanks to lemma 3.6, for any positive integer ùëùpp there exists a constant subscriptùëê1c1c_{1} such that

Now, let us prove that ùëÜSS is a contraction in superscriptsubscriptùëÜùëùùõøSpŒ¥S_{p}^{\delta}.
